active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group debate, argue whether parameter tampering should be a standard step in every API pentest, considering time constraints, false positives, and differences between REST and GraphQL APIs. Provide real-world examples.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Students pair up; one student explains parameter tampering in REST APIs using a live demo (e.g., via Postman on JSONPlaceholder), while the partner teaches back the differences in GraphQL (e.g., tampering with variables or arguments) and quizzes the first student on OWASP-related risks.
active_learning.problem_solving: Using a mock vulnerable API (e.g., JSONPlaceholder or a local DVWA API), students tamper parameters to bypass Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR), such as changing 'user_id=123' to 'user_id=456' to retrieve unauthorized data. Debrief on observed vulnerabilities and mitigations like proper authorization checks.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding
